li.p: Use the relationship between the zeros of a polynomial and the factored form to find a graphing window or to write an equation.
Sketch or describe the possible shape of a polynomial function of degree n including: the number of turning points, number of possible real roots, and end behavior.

section.title: Gist of Power Functions and Polynomials

subsection.title: Power Functions
subsection.p: A Power Functionfunctionpower function is a single-term function of the form y = ax^k where a and k are constant numbers.

For us, the important characteristic of a power function is the shape of its graph, and in particular, the tendency of the graph as x gets very far from zero. This tendency is referred to as the end-behaviorend-behaviorfunctionend-behavior of the function.
Power functions of the form y = x^k when k is an even number (2, 4, 6, \cdots), all resemble x^2, in the sense that their output values constantly increase as x \to \infty or x \to -\infty.
We would say that power functions with even exponents all have similar end-behavior the graph keeps increasing forever when x gets far from zero.

Power functions of the form y = x^k when k is an odd number (1, 3, 5, \cdots), all resemble y = x, in the sense that their output values constantly increase as x \to \infty, and they decrease as x \to -\infty.
Similarly, we would say that power functions with odd exponents all have similar end-behavior the graph increases on one side, and it decreases on the other, as x gets far from zero.

statement.p: If you have ever stood on the end of a diving board, your weight caused the board to deflect that is, it bent downward a bit toward the water below. If the board was longer, it would deflect more, and if it was shorter, it would deflect less.

Assuming one end of the board is fixed solidly to a wall, and the other end is free to move up and down, then engineers could use the following equation to model the weight required to deflect a board of a given length L: W = \frac{3 \delta E I}{L^3}

Here, \delta is the deflection (inches), E is a physical constant called Young's Modulus of Elasticity (in^4), I is a geometric constant called the Area Moment of Inertia (\frac{lb}{in^2}), and L is the length of the board (inches).
So, W is a power function with the variable L.
Professional diving boards are typically between 177 and 201 inches long. See a portion of the graph of W = W(L) below.
Notice the slight curve to this graph and that it is concave up. Is there a horizontal asymptote for this function? Why?

solution.p: Even with a large coefficient, the power function \frac{1}{L^3} still goes to zero as L \to \infty.
This makes sense, because as the length of the board gets longer and longer, it would require a smaller and smaller weight in order to deflect the board by 6 inches.

[However, the weight of the board itself would tend to cause significant deflection as the length increased. This function would work to model only boards of moderate length, and it should not be used for boards which are extremely long.]

subsection.title: Polynomials
subsection.p: Polynomialspolynomial are functions of the form: y = a_nx^n + a_{n−1}x^{n−1} + \cdots + a_1x + a_0 where the numbers a_0, a_1, \cdots, a_{n-1}, a_n are some constant real numbers, called coefficientscoefficientspolynomialcoefficients.
Note that some of the coefficients may be zero.

remark.p: It is common to write an arbitrary list of values like a_1, a_2, \cdots, a_n when we don't know (or don't want to specify) how many there are in the list. The subscript n just means that the list is not infinitely long.

subsection.p: Here are some examples of polynomials you already know: \text{The line } y = 3x - 7 \text{The parabola } y = x^2 + 1
The degreepolynomialdegre of a polynomial is the value of the highest exponent in the formula.
So our parabola y = x^2 + 1 has degree 2, and our line y = 3x − 7 has degree 1.
The exponents of a polynomial can only be non-negative integers. That means functions likey = x^\frac{1}{2}andy = 2x^3 - x^{-5}are not polynomials.

statement.p: Which of the functions below are polynomials? f(x) \amp= x^5 - \frac{2}{x} g(x) \amp= 2 + 6x^3 h(x) \amp= \frac{11x^3+4x}{9\pi} p(x) \amp= 5\sqrt{x}+9 q(x) \amp= (6x-2)(5x^3-2x+7) r(x) \amp= \log_7(4)x(x+\sqrt{12.8})

hint.p: You may do some algebra to simplify a function before deciding if it is a polynomial.

answer.p: The functions f(x) and p(x) are not polynomials, but the others are.
The coefficients may be complicated, as when simplifying r(x): r(x)= \log_7(4)x^2 + \log_7(4)\sqrt{12.8}x

subsection.p: The coefficients can be positive, negative or zero. In the 4^{\rm{th}} degree polynomial y \amp= −5x^4+2x^3−x^1+0.69x^0 \amp= -5x^4 + 2x^3 - x + 0.69 the coefficient of x^3 is 2, and the coefficient of x^2 is 0 (because there is no x^2 term).

The term with the highest power of x is called the leading termpolynomialleading term, and the coefficient of x^0 is called the constant termpolynomialconstant term. In the polynomial above, the leading term is -5x^4 and the constant term is 0.69.
When polynomials are multiplied together, the result will also a polynomial, and the degree of this new polynomial is just the sum of the degrees of the formulas you multiplied together.

example.p: The two linear (1^{\rm{st}} degree) polynomials7x + 2and5x + 4will create a 2^{\rm{nd}} degree polynomial when multiplied together:

Recall from Chapter, that if we named the linear functions f(x) = 7x + 2 and g(x) = 5x + 4, then the 2^{\rm{nd}} degree polynomial 35x^2 + 38x + 8 above may be thought of as the function combination:f(x)\cdot g(x)

subsection.p: An input value which gives an output of zero is called a rootrootpolynomialroot of the polynomial, and a root corresponds to an x-intercept of the polynomial's graph.

example.p: The values x \amp= 3 x \amp= \frac{1}{2} x \amp= -4 are all roots of the polynomial: f(x) = 8x^3 + 4x^2 - 100x + 48
To confirm this, we could either:

li.p: Evaluate f\left(3\right), f\left(\frac{1}{2}\right) and f(-4), and see that they each give zero as the output. (Try this!)
Graph the function y = f(x) and observe that it contains the x-intercepts (3, 0), \left(\frac{1}{2}, 0\right) and (-4, 0).

paragraphs.title: Finding the Formula for a Polynomial
paragraphs.p: If you know the roots of a polynomial, you can easily create a list of linear factors (lines of degree 1) which have those same roots. Then, multiplying those linear factors together will create a polynomial which has all of those roots.

example.p: In Example, we were told that the polynomial had the roots 3, \frac{1}{2} and -4.
If we wanted to write the formula for f(x), using only this information, we could create the linear factors: \left(x - 3\right) (x - \frac{1}{2}) \left(x + 4\right)
Multiplying these factors together \left(x-3\right)(x-\frac{1}{2})\left(x+4\right) gives a polynomial which has all three of those roots.
Note: This polynomial is not the same as f(x) from Example, though it does have the same roots.

subsection.p: Now, beyond just making a polynomial have particular roots, you can also vertically stretch or compress your function in order to adjust the shape, making it pass through any other point you may know on the polynomial.

example.p: Suppose we know that a polynomial f(x) has the roots x \amp= 5 x \amp= -6 x \amp= 9 and that it also contains the point (4,2).
We can determine a polynomial which has these characteristics by creating linear factors which have the given roots: x = 5 \amp\implies (x - 5) x = -6 \amp\implies (x + 6) x = 9 \amp\implies (x - 9)

Multiplying these factors together will make a polynomial which has the given roots: y = (x-5)(x+6)(x-9)However, it does not pass through the point (4, 2), because using the input x = 4 gives: y \amp= (4-5)(4+6)(4-9) \amp= (-1)(10)(-5) \amp= 50

In order to make our polynomial also pass through the point (4,2), we will use a vertical compression. We know this must be a compression, because our function currently has an output of 50 when the input is 4 we want the output to be only 2.
For the vertical compression, we include a constant factor k to our function: y = k(x-5)(x+6)(x-9)
Notice that multiplying by a constant k does not change the roots of the function.
In order to determine the value of k that will work here, we use the point (4,2), substituting 4 for x, and 2 for y: 2 \amp= k(4-5)(4+6)(4-9) 2 \amp= k(50) k \amp= \frac{2}{50} \amp=0.04
Therefore, we have a polynomial which passes through (4,2) and has the correct roots:y = 0.04(x-5)(x+6)(x-9)

paragraphs.title: Repeated Roots
paragraphs.p: Linear factors may be repeated, as in: y \amp= x(x+1)^2(x-6)^4 \amp= x(x+1)(x+1)(x-6)(x-6)(x-6)(x-6)

Since a linear factor (x-a) corresponds to a root x = a, then repeating a linear factor will give us a repeated root. A repeated rootrepeated rootpolynomialrepeated root is a root of a polynomial caused by a repeated linear factor.
If a linear factor is repeated k times, then we say the root it creates has multiplicitymultiplicityrootmultiplicity k.

example.p: The polynomial y = x^3(x-5)^2 has only two roots: x = 0 and x = 5.
We say the root x = 0 has multiplicity 3, and the root x = 5 has multiplicity 2.

subsection.p: How does a repeated root affect the graph? We know that a root will appear as an x-intercept on the graph, but will repeating a root in a formula mean the x-intercept is somehow also repeated?
In Chapter, we learned to shift a parabola left or right, just by adding a number to the input. For example:y = (x+3)^2is the parabola x^2 moved to the left by 3 units.
This parabola has just one root which has been repeated twice, and the graph appears to bounce off of the x-axis at the root.
This phenomenon of bouncing remains a characteristic of the graph, even if we give a polynomial more linear factors, such as: y = (x+3)^2(x-1)
subsection.todo: Fix the following graph, then learn how to make graphs that aren't disgusting
subsection.p: Notice that the root x = -3 has multiplicity 2, and the graph resembles a parabola near that point, bouncing off of the x-axis. It also has the root x = 1, which has multiplicity 1, and the graph crosses over the x-axis there.
The polynomials below both have (x+3)^2 as a factor, but they have other linear factors with either odd or even multiplicity:

Notice that when the multiplicity of a root is evenmultiplicityeven, the graph bounces off of the x-axis at that value. When the multiplicity of a root is oddmultiplicityodd, the graph crosses over the x-axis at that value.

statement.p: The graph below shows a polynomial y = f(x).

[@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/qUku8jCM/width/425/height/373/border/888888/sdz/false/" width="425px" height="373px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
Which of the following options could be the formula for f(x)?

hint.p: Notice the behavior of the graph near x = -1 and x = 3. Those roots have even multiplicities.

solution.p: The only viable option is f(x) = (x+1)^2(x-1)(x-3)^2, since the graph bounces off the points (-1, 0) and (3, 0), and crosses over the point (1, 0).
In general, our best guess for the formula would be something that looked like: (x+1)^\text{even}(x-1)^\text{odd}(x-3)^\text{even}

subsection.p: You probably noticed that while an even multiplicity of a root causes the graph to bounce off of the x-axis, sometimes the graph is below the x-axis and sometimes it is above the x-axis.
What causes this? How can we predict whether the graph will be above the x-axis or below it?
The reason for this has to do with the end-behavior of the whole function. That is, the graph of a polynomial will eventually either increase or decrease forever as x gets far from zero.
Since the end-behavior of a function is the tendency of the graph as x \rightarrow \infty or x \to -\infty, we may ask how to determine this without having to graph the function.

example.p: A table of values for the function f(x) = x^3 - 45x^2 + 12x - 20 is shown below.
So far, it appears that the function is decreasing as x increases. However, continuing the table shows a change in the behavior:
Initially, the function was decreasing very quickly, but eventually it turned around and began to increase (even faster). In fact, this function will eventually increase forever as x \to \infty.
We can make sense of this by considering the formula for f(x) and imagining substituting a very large value of x.

subsection.p: The point here is that raising a large value to the power of 3 is much more significant than raising it to the power of 2 (or any smaller power). As another piece of math terminology, we would say that the term x^3 dominates the other terms. The highest power of x is most significant in the end, so we can just focus our attention on the leading term of a polynomial to determine the end-behavior.
In summary:

assemblage.p: A polynomial has the same end-behavior as its leading term.

subsection.p: Similarly, we can ask what the graph tends to do as x \to -\infty. This will be the same as the leading term x^3, which eventually decreases forever as x \to -\infty.
In the next exercise, we show the steps for graphing a polynomial. Following these steps, you can sketch the graph of a polynomial by hand.

statement.p: In this problem, we will make a rough sketch of the graph of the polynomial: f(x) = x(x+3)(x-2)^2
First, we know that the x-intercepts are at x=0, x=-3 and x=2.
Next, in expanded form, the leading term would be x^4. This tells us the end-behavior of the graph.
Finally, the multiplicity of the roots tells us whether the graph crosses or bounces off of the x-axis.
In the graph below, use the slider to show steps for graphing this function.

[@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/MRSRj24k/width/425/height/373/border/888888/smb/false/stb/false/stbh/false/ai/false/asb/false/sri/false/rc/false/ld/false/sdz/false/ctl/false" width="425px" height="373px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
Make a rough sketch of the graph of the polynomial f(x) = (x-4)(x-1)^2(x+3)^2(x+5).
We must use what we know about the roots and their multiplicities, and also the end-behavior of the function.

li.p: First, plot the x-intercepts on your graph. Remember that these are determined by finding the roots of the function.

Next, consider the end-behavior of the polynomial. Do this by deciding what the leading term would be if it was completely expanded. On the far left and far right side of the graph, draw arrows to show what the graph will eventually do (increasing or decreasing).

Finally, use what you know about the multiplicity of each root. Beginning at your arrow on the far left side of the graph, draw a smooth curve which contains all of the x-intercepts you drew in the first step. When you get to an x-intercept, if its multiplicity is odd, the graph will cross over the x-axis, and if the multiplicity is even, the graph will bounce off of the x-axis. Your smooth curve should end at the arrow you drew on the far right hand side.

statement.p: Check the graph. If drawn correctly, you should have been able to draw from your arrow on the left side to the arrow on the right side without picking up your pencil.

hint.p: The roots are x = 4 x = 1 x = -3 x = -5
If expanded, the leading term would be the power function x^6, so the end-behavior would be increasing on both the left and right sides of the graph.

answer.p: Notice that the graph crosses the x-axis at x = -5 and x = 4, and it bounces off of the x-axis at x = -3 and x = 1.

introduction.p: Graphs of Power Functions and Polynomials
Degree, Roots, Multiplicities and End Behavior
